Tax Justice Network Africa - reducing tax evasion

description.narrative:
Tax Justice Network Africa (TJN-A) was established in 2007 and today counts 29 member organizations from 16 countries all across Africa. The organization aims at reducing tax evasion and works in favor of fair tax systems in the member countries and all over the continent. The present funding proposal is the first support ever from Sida, why the scope is limited to 18 months (1 April 2016 to 30 September 2017) and a maximum amount of SEK 4,9 million. Should the cooperation generate good results then a longer-term commitment may be considered. The funding has the character of core support for financing TJN-A's Strategic Plan 2016-2020 which contains many elements related to the follow-up on the Mbeki High Level Report on Illicit Financial Flows from Africa, particularly focusing on tax evasion. The strategic plan as a whole addresses the following development problems:
1) Lack of inclusive, transparent and effective multilateral systems to shape and regulate global financial institutions resulting in illicit outflow of financial resources from Africa.
2) Ineffective and unfair investment and tax treaties and harmful tax incentives that encourage tax competition to the bottom between countries and erode the domestic tax bases.
3) Inadequate fiscal regimes governing extractive sector in resource rich Africa countries resulting in inadequate tax revenues and benefits from the extractives.
4) Regressive tax systems that increase the burden to the low income earners and thus aggravates inequality.

The project has one main objective and three sub objectives as indicated below. Main Objective: It is to advocate for policy measures that will contribute to curbing illicit financial flows from Africa and to enable African nations to seal loopholes that allow tax dodging. Sub objectives: • Advocate for the implementation of AU/UNECA High level Panel on IFFs from Africa recommendations by African countries• Support research and policy analysis in the implementation of global transparency measures such as Country-by-Country-Reporting and Automatic Exchange of Information to the African context• Support capacity building of CSOs, the media, trade unions, student groups and other relevant non-state stakeholders to engage in policy discussions at the national level on IFF related issues.

description.narrative: The following are the major achievements. . TJNA together with several partners have published a series of reports highlighting the dangers of tax competition in East and West Africa as well as the dangers of tax treaties with tax havens. . EAC Tax Treaty Policy and the EAC Model Tax adopted including Double Taxation Agreement . Beneficial ownership legislation adopted and established in South Africa, Ghana incorporated Beneficial Ownership disclosure clause in the planned amendment of the Companies’ Act 1963 (Act 179) and in Kenya the company’s act have been amended through a parliamentary bill to introduce beneficial ownerships of shares in Kenyan companies. .TJNA developed as part of different global CSO groups’ statements and analytical pieces on advocating for the broad definition of IFFs that includes aggressive tax avoidance. .TJNA delivered a statement on behalf of the Civil Society FfD Group that emphasised the need for a deeper understanding of the ecosystem of Illicit Financial Flows (IFFs); the importance of widening the scope of defining IFFs; and the need for a Global Intergovernmental Tax body under the UN to combat IFFs. . As a result of TJNA and other partners advocacy works UN General Assembly has adopted by consensus a Nigeria-sponsored resolution to promote international cooperation to combat illicit financial flows in order to foster sustainable development. . TJNA and its partners launched the campaign to new stakeholders including Faith based leaders, students and academics, and trade unions representing the public services sector. 5. African Parliamentary Network on Illicit Financial Flows and Tax (APNIFFT) has grown from just 10 members in 2015 to 72 in 2017 as a result of TJNA’s tailored capacity building programme for MPs, technical support for MPs to debate tax justice and IFFs issues and creation of platform for MPs at global, continental, and national levels to speak on tax justice and IFFs. 6. TJNA adopted a structured partnership approach to provide a valuable platform for outcome harvesting within the secretariat and among the members especially in the scaling up tax justice programme.
